Comment: I'm curious here. Was black's (ultimately winning) reply on move 22 really sound? - It worked out well for me but looks risky.

As a regular Sicilian player, I see this a lot, even from players rated a little higher than me. It does not scare me. It used to, when I first started playing the Sicilian as white immediately threatens f7 but...

...black can achieve equality very easily.
Not sure if I understand the point of this move. Fear of a queen's knight advance via c8 to b4?
This move is intended to relieve the pressure on b2? - white has restricted the space that his knight can develop into and does not seem to have gained very much for it.

Ditto. Black would seem to have the advantage here, in my opinion.
Begins to threaten at white's defences - too early? - black maybe should have developed its white bishop to b7 before attempting this?
A straight exchange... but weakens white's defences for his castled king.
A straight exchange... but weakens white's defences for his castled king.
Further weakens the defences around the white's king - in the hope of a blunder from black?
Obvious move is obvious.
White doesn't seem to have much to threaten with yet... maybe should have found a way to develop the knight before mounting this attack?
Offers the exchange.
Exchange taken... the white king's position is again, just a little weaker.

Maybe white has control of the centre but black seems to have an equal claim. I still think black has the advantage... weirdly, I didn't feel so confident here when playing the game as when I look at this position now.
